headline: Refrigerator Dill Pickles
description: Easy refrigerator dill pickles perfectly seasoned with just the right amount of dill ang garlic. Crisp, delicious spears, ready to eat in just 3 days!

video.description: You’ll be shocked by how easy it is to make refrigerator pickles at home. This top-rated recipe for refrigerator dill pickles utilizes simple ingredients–like water, vinegar, sugar, and salt–and is seasoned with the perfect amount of dill and garlic.
video.name: How to Make Refrigerator Crunchy Dill Pickles | Quick Pickles

name: Refrigerator Dill Pickles

recipeInstructions.text: Stir water, vinegar, sugar, and sea salt together in a saucepan over high heat; bring to a boil. Remove from the heat and cool completely.
Combine cucumber spears, garlic cloves, and fresh dill in a large glass or plastic lidded container.
Pour cooled vinegar mixture over cucumbers, garlic, and dill.
Seal container with lid and refrigerate for at least 3 days.

review.reviewBody: Followed the recipe adding extra garlic and mustard seed
Very tasty. I used different sizes of containers so my garlic and dill ratio was a little different in each jar... but they were still yummy.

I ended up leaving the finished pickles in their jar for about nine days. I don't know if that affected anything, but they turned out very well. They got good reviews at the Labor Day family gathering :o)
Added chili flakes for a bit of zest.

These are great and easy to make! Especially when you have a bunch more cukes and you don't want to can them! I didn't have fresh dill so I added 1 tablespoon of pickling spice and a few smashed garlic cloves! They definatley get more flavor after a week or so in fridge, and they stay fresh & crunchy tasting! Making a second batch today, first batch is almost gone! I also used a recycled giant glass jar that had olives in them!
OMG I LOVE this recipe. I will never buy dill pickles in a store again! Did not use fresh dill, as I already had some that I had previously dried. Still darn good
This is nothing more than a cucumber salad. Nothing at all like pickles, not even close, it's like cucumber salad.

This is my second year making this recipe. Actually, this is my second year making pickles at all!!! They are absolutely delicious. I grow my own cukes and dill. I've never tasted a better pickle. Great recipe.

This recipe came out amazing! If I can do it, so can anyone else out there. FYI I used white vinegar. I did not know how much 2 heads of dill quite equated to. So I put 3-4 pieces of it in the jar. Also added a couple more cloves of garlic. Not sure if that makes a huge difference. Still the flavor did come out excellent.
These bombed big time with the family. The sugar is a no go.
Used this recipe for several years, I love it! Pickles are.crisp!
I validate: Super tasty and uncomplicated. I made pickles for the time and the recipe worked like a charm.
This recipe is super easy and delicious!
Very nice and Tasty Pickles - As maintaining standards and quality since many years.

This was the 1st recipe I ever used for pickling. Pickles came out halfway decent. 2nd batch I kind of did it myself and they did not come out that well now I am on my 3rd batch and I'm using this recipe again . Very easy to use highly recommend for the 1st timer grab some cucumbers slice then up throw them in some pickle jars throw in the ingredients 3 days later you have pickles enjiy

This is a great simple recipe. I made it exactly as is originally and then again recently, but I changed some things and it turned out great both times. For people who want a smaller batch, you can half the recipe and it is still great. For a half batch, I used 1.5 tbsp of dried dill and it worked great. I also like to add the dried dill when I am heating the vinegar mixture. Also, if you don’t have a mason jar, plastic takeout soup containers also work perfectly.

So easy to make and soooo... good! As others have said, be sure to wait at least the full three days or even a little longer. I tried a taste after two days, then again after five days. The difference was dramatic.
Super easy, but didn't know how much was 2 heads of dill so I didn't know how much to put. They weren't dill enough. If you wonder if you put enough, add more But they were still good.
Easy recipe . Delicious. A good way to get rid of those extra cucumbers in the garden. I had enough cucumbers to make 3 jars full. I think a little less dill.
I had never made pickles before and I used this and absolutely loved the flavor. They were easy to make and I will continue to use this recipe.
I used red wine vinegar and cut them in slices.
Awesome! I made it with cukes from the garden, and it turned out great!
So easy and so good. Did add just a little pickling spice.
This is a great recipe! Followed the directions to the letter and the pickles were crisp and so tasty! Love this recipe!
Good basic recipe. Easy to make with readily available ingredients. I added pickle crisp.
This an easy a delicious recipe. I also out a little red pepper flakes in.

Fool proof and exquisite every time. I’ll never buy pickles again. I buy fresh ingredients and make in minutes. The hardest part is waiting for the flavors to meld in the fridge for 3 days. If you love pickles but shy away from them for health reasons, this is a recipe for you. I use Himalayan sea salt and organic produce for a superior product with no chemicals, the way food is supposed to be. I don’t feel bad about letting my family eat these at all.
Light dill flavor, but so fresh tasting it's still a keeper! I would add extra dill and chop my garlic next time.

I have made these several times and they are always good. I can't find heads of dill so I just throw a few springs in. Also I use apple cider vinegar, as regular white vinegar is almost too strong for my tastes. The brine you can keep and use a few more times. Little zucchinis also work and are good!
Loved the results! so crisp and refreshing.
Easy to make and yummy. Sometimes I add a a couple pieces of hot pepper to spice it up
Easy to make and yummy. Sometimes I add a a couple pieces of hot pepper to spice it up

First time ever making pickles, enjoyed the ease of this recipe without having to do the whole canning bit. The hardest part is waiting for your liquid to cool off, my pickles stayed in the refrigerator for 1 to 2 weeks before I let anyone try them I brought them to work everybody loved them! Definitely delicious, you can mix up the recipe contents of the jar anyway you want just use the base liquid recipe
Great recipe! We used cucumbers from my son's garden, and they were great! We added 1/2 teaspoon of red crushed pepper flakes to each jar. Crispy, tasty dill pickles!
I have never commented on a recipe. This is amazing. Crisp and perfect. highly recommend trying this.
My husband looks forward to these every year when I grow cucs. They keep in the fridge for a very long time and stay fresh. Highly recommend use a good pickling cucumber is my only suggestion.
Just finished eating my pickles. Four jars lasted 26 days. Pretty darn good. Going to make more! Good on day one, fantastic on day 26.

I didn't have fresh dill, so I subbed in a teaspoon of dried. This is THE best tart pickle I've ever had. They came together so easily, and I had trouble leaving them alone once I'd tasted them. I have never been a huge pickle eater; this was just something I was doing with extra cucumbers from the farmer's market. I'm doing them by the half-gallon now.

I thought this was an excellent recipe. I added a couple fresh ripe cayenne peppers from the garden. Gave them just a bit of kick. Highly recommend. Today I'm going to try this brine with only jalapenos, habaneros, and a few pickles. Wish me luck!

Wow, these pickles are so good and so easy to make! Key things to remember are to cool the vinegar mixture completely and make sure the cucumbers are very cold for extra crispiness. (I soak mine in an ice water bath.) I also put in some extra baby carrots and onions. I think they taste best after about 5 days in the fridge. Before that time the small cucumbers were still bitter and not pickled enough. I'll definitely make this recipe again!

These were great, such a simple recipe! 
I made 3 16-oz jars of pickles following this recipe, I left one as-is, in another one I added black peppercorns and in the last one I added red pepper flakes. 

My pickles sat for 3 days before I tried them yesterday, they were great but today they are even better--so light, refreshing and crunchy!
My son loves pickles, so this recipe was a perfect project for us to do together with cucumbers from our garden.
Exvellent! Shared with my co-workers. They loved them. The longer they refrigerate, the better they get.
First attempt making pickles and I'm never going back. So good.
Didn’t know pickles could be this easy! I may run out of jars before I run out of cucumbers!! A definite keeper AND going in the family’s “Tested Best” book!
Added some jalapeno and more garlic than was called for.

This was great! I don't like sweet pickles, so I eliminated the sugar and instead added some pickling spice. (I made half-recipe to try, so I used about a half teaspoon of pickling spice to each of three jars.) I love these pickles and will definitely make them again, especially as we have so many cucumbers from the garden.

I followed the recipe with the exception of cutting some of the pickles into chips. They were extremely delicious, even after only 1 day in the refrigerator. 3 days in and they are great. They remind me of Claussens which are the only brand I typically buy. I've eaten so many after 3 days that I chopped up a few more cucumbers from the garden and added them to the brine. I'll be curious to see how the added pickles do.

This is a fantastic, simple recipe. I used 2 tbsp of freeze dried dill instead of fresh dill and it worked just as well. I used regular waxed cucumbers sliced and that worked just fine too. They were crunchy and delicious. I will make these many more times!
First time I've tried making dill pickles. The best dill pickles I've ever had.
These were so easy to make and taste fantastic
It was a nice refreshing pickle. Simple and easy recipe

I have been making these refrigerator pickles every year. They do need to be refrigerated for at least 1-2 weeks before you start using them. It's hard to eat just a few, that why I alternate the type of slices: thin, thick, long, round, etc. Really good on sandwiches and burgers. Give it a try!
I had to make another batch of brine to fill my jars since I had large cucumbers. I'm making it again though - good taste!
Thank you! These are the best pickles ever! Only making these from now on! Yummy!
These turned out great, and got better the longer they stayed in the fridge. I will probably add a little more salt next time, just due to personal taste, but otherwise I loved them.

These pickles are far superior to anything that has gone through the canning process. I use pickling cucumbers always with a little standard pickling spices. But using different kinds of vinegars create unbelievably delicious variations cucumbers. My favorite is white balsamic vinegar I get from Trader Joes.
Easy, fresh and the best crispy dill pickles.
I tried this recipe and every one loves them. I made 50 jars this year and I only have 2 left. Unbelievable

I have made this twice this season. I added more dill because I like it and I had a lot growing. More garlic, same reason, some pickling spices and 1/4 cup less water, plus 1:4 cup more vinegar and some sweet heat peppers which I love.

These turned out perfectly. I did replace one cup of white vinegar with unfiltered cider vinegar. They taste great and have a good snap too. I may add more dill and garlic next time for variety. They are disappearing fast!
Perfect....minimal salt, and tasty crunchy pickles that are a breeze to make. I cut the recipe in half.

Substituted cider vinegar for white vinegar because that's what I had. Regrettably, will NOT do that again. It was way too sweet for my quest of a truly dill pickle. Might work well for bread and butter pickles but definitely not dill. Otherwise, texture was crunchy as desired. Will definitely make again!
Nice crisp pickles with good flavor

I didn't measure out my cucumbers because I had a ton. I just cut what I had into spears & put them in quart mason jars with a nice clump of dill & 2 garlic cloves per jar. They turned out very good - nice & crisp & the garlic gives them a spicy flavor (not hot just flavorful).

 My husband who grew up with his grandma's homemade pickles & he absolutely loved these & wants me to make some more.
Easy and super good!
I used this recipe as a base for canned pickles. They turned out very delicious. Thanks!
So good, quick and easy.

Delicious and they actually taste like DILL pickles! That said, I ran out of sugar and only had a sprinkling when I made them, so I will continue to do that with further jars as I do not like sweet pickles at all, and this was just right with only the sprinkle. 

I also didn't have fresh garlic and used garlic powder instead. Tasted great. In one jar, I threw in some black pepper and a few red pepper flakes and they were even better as I like things a little spicy, but the milder pickles were good, too.
I make this every year and they are perfect. This will be my last batch for this summer as my plant has given out.

This is very good basic recipe. Thank you. When you just want a good tasting fresh pickle & are overwhelmed with cucumbers from the garden, this is a go to. More importantly, the jars of pickles are easier to get rid of (pass off onto friends, family & neighbors) than just a plain old cucumber. People enjoy these.
wonderful and simple. I used dill weed, 2 tablespoons.
I started making these last year and made more this year. I added carrots to a couple jars so that they would look pretty. Delicious and less sodium than store bought. Thanks.

I had some cucumbers come in early. Not enough for a big batch. This year I also had far my green beans than I knew what to do with. So I made some more and have pickled the green breads. Need to give them a few more days to see how they turn out.
These were very good; I used cucumbers from my garden, and they turned out crisp and flavorful. Very easy to make.

Growing dill in my garden, which all came at the same time so I had to do something. I was able to fit a ton of dill with 2 onions, 8 large pickle sized cucs and a butt load of garlic. Used 3T of salt instead of 1of and boiled 1C vinegar with 1C water. Cooled it with 4C of ice.
Love this recipe of all those I have tried. I do add whole black pepper and most recently, red pepper flakes.
I add black peppercorn, onion, and jalapeño for a spicy variety.

Made these probably about 2-3 weeks ago now. This was my first time making pickles at home and this was a really great recipe to start with. My mom and I added the recommended amount of everything but possibly more dill than listed though. They came out wonderful! I've eaten half the jar already! The only downside I have encountered is that some of the spears have a bitter taste to them, especially on the ends? I can't think of why though. I don't think a little added dill would do that but maybe. I didn't use "pickling cucumbers" per se, just small ones a local farm grows. Definitely going to make them again!
Easy and delicious, the pickles run out a day after they're ready

Really good recipe and easy to make. I didn't measure the pickle slices because i had a bunch of cukes from the garden I ended up doubling the pickling brine and put them in a Cambro.

They turned out awesome. Dill flavor is great. I did have sea salt but you could use Kosher. 

Second batch I added a couple of sliced jalapeno's and some pepper flakes for a spicy dill. They were the bomb.

This is a great recipe as written. It's easy to make, the 3 day brine is perfect and they are crunchy and delicious. Recommend it definitely.

I made these pickles last week. I minced my garlic. They smelled just like the pickles you get with a sandwich at a Deli. Several people tried the pickles . Everyone enjoyed them. I did receive a few compliments. I will make them again. I will serve them at cookouts. This recipe will be great to have on hand when my cukes are ready to pick from the garden! A+++
These pickles were a huge hit with my wife. I used the mini cucumbers found at Aldi and added red pepper flakes along with the other ingredients.
Super easy, super delicious. So good on a hamburger

I’ve made all sorts of canned pickles in the past but this refrigerator dill pickle recipe is by far the best type of pickle I’ve made. I made about eight or nine jars at the end of the summer with the pickles I had left in my garden and my whole family enjoyed them until the last jar was gone. They lasted until about Thanksgiving.
I love this. So simple and the pickles come out perfect. I use slices of my home grown freshly picked cucumbers. These pickles end up crunchy and very tasty. I have made them 8 times.
Very easy and the family loves it!
Really good. I made jar after jar as they were eaten.

I gave a neutral rating because this is the first time using this recipe. Currently I have the brine in the refrigerator to cool. I am going to use it for Poblano as well as Serrano peppers.

I hope this recipe will achieve something similar to the commercial pickled Jalapeños.
I went with the recipe as per but not sure of the exact amount of fresh dill so I just went with what it looked right.

I’ll besure to update in a few days.
No. And I will make more! Great recipe! Thank you!
These were great! My husband really liked them!
Super simple with great results. One tip is to leave it longer in the fridge before consuming - it will give a better taste the longer it is left to pickle.

Turned out great, each and every time.
Thank you Thank you!

These are the best pickles I’ve ever had - and extremely easy to make. I doubled the recipe, and had to use fresh baby dill as it was the only thing I had. Also added a little celery seed and some peppercorns to the brine ...By day 4 they were perfect!
Awesome recipe!!!!
We are not a fan of dill, but love garlic! With 3 years of pickle making, here’s what is loved the best here...
Great recipe! I'm kicking up the garlic for batch 2.

Excellent!! The garlic adds so much. We also add slices of sweet onion (Vidalia or Wala Wala). The pickled onion is great on salads. We have also used this same recipe when canning our dills. Results were amazing!!
A very crunchy pickle. I like it mine a bit more salty, garlicky and dill so I will just add more.
